title: Can we use poster colour paint on my face? - Quora

response.answer_text: Using anything on the skin that is not intended for such use (what I often refer to as “The Wrong Stuff” and including poster paint, acrylic paint, and oil paint) is a really, really bad idea. The first thing that can go wrong is, you will have trouble getting it off (see Girl covers her face in bright pink ‘wash off paint’... and this is how it looks after). The second thing is that you can have a reaction and/or poison yourself—and you may not even know you’ve poisoned yourself right away as sometimes the effects of certain things leeching into the bloodstream from the skin takes weeks, months, or years to become apparent. Stick to body art cosmetics intended for use on the skin such as TAG, Paradise, Diamond FX, Global, Cameleon, Ruby Red, and Snazaroo (among others). I happen to use TAG myself but will agree to get painted with just about anything that’s intended for face/body art and not “The Wrong Stuff”.

Absolutely not. You don’t know what kind of a reaction your skin is going to have to poster paint. If it is not meant for the skin then I would use it all. Especially near sensitive places like the eyes and mouth. There are plenty of high pigment makeups on the market which can be used with oil or water to create different effects. There are also face-painting specific paints like Snazaroo. Using paints and make-up which are specifically designed for use on the face will make sure you don’t get a nasty shock!

The skin on the face is very delicated. Use only professional product especifically indicated for face painting. Consider that apparently harmless craft paints, which usually have a “non-toxic” label, contain formaldehyde. This is a nocive substance and can cause at least important allergic reactions (and even cancer). Moreover, even low quality face paints should not be used on the face either. Thus the answer to this question is obviusly a great “NO”. You can find more information here Ultimate Face Painting Tutorial for Beginners: Your step-by-step guide for learning how to face paint

You can use poster paint (tempera paint) on your face IF you want to risk skin irritation, staining, etc, which can happen since it’s not hypoallergenic, or has ingredients meant for skin, etc. Instead you should use the various paints, etc, out there that are intended for skin—they don’t have to be expensive and are even more available just before Halloween:https://www.google.com/search?q=paints+safe+for+skin&oq=paints+safe+for+skin

No!!! Poster paint is a really poor and uncomfortable substitute for proper face paint. If you would like to achieve a nice result and not create an itchy, flakey mess on your skin… then pro quality face paints are really the only option. Try Face Paint Shop Australia — the best brands inc Tag, Global, Cameleon, Kryvaline, Party Xplosion, Face Paints Australia.
